caption: One of the most important landmarks of Paris, located close to both Notre-Dame and Louvre, serving as a bridge over the beautiful Seine. üá´üá∑ ‚Ä¶
A most cleverly constructed bridge, not only giving access at road level on either side of the river, but also having cutaways leading down to the opposing quaysides.

The Passerelle L√©opold-S√©dar-Senghor is a pedestrian bridge in Paris that elegantly spans the Seine, connecting the Tuileries Gardens and the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay. Made of steel and wood, its design harmonizes with the surrounding architecture and offers a sleek, modern aesthetic. From the bridge, visitors can enjoy picturesque views of the river and the city‚Äôs landmarks. The bridge also features seating areas, inviting pedestrians to pause and soak in the scenery. Named after the Senegalese poet and statesman, it symbolizes cultural and artistic connections.

This is a very popular bridge especially with tourists as it is a nice easy way, (avoiding traffic) to get from the Gardens Tuileries to the Musee d‚ÄôOrsay, we love the architectural quirkiness of it as you can access the bank with a walkway on the spanning arch.
Walking bridge that crosses the Seine, not that architecturally outstanding but it serves its purpose. Offers beautiful views.

It's a bridge connecting garden Tuileries to Musee D'orsay.  Slightly wobbly with gaps so people with bad vertigo don't look down.  Good views down the Seine and lots of locks on the bridge.  Don't waste your money.

Take a little break walk out from Jardin des Tuileries, here comes the famous bridge of love locks. Interesting to see east side, with better views and much more going on, has way more, super packed, locks than the west side, makes you thinking that love is not as unconditional, for better for worse thru thick and thin, as it suppose to be Someday it'll tilt. Jokes aside, this is a very beautiful bridge, you can see all kinds of views, people, activities, even police patrol boat rushing under.

It's a lovely bridge with a lovely view. And with all the locks had been taken off arts. This was the new love lock bridge HOWEVER someone was CUTTING OFF the LOCKS, he was not in uniform. Most likely an angry local that took it upon him self with bolt cutters and a angle grinder to cut off the locks. His about a third done from the south moving north.  It's such a shame that this is happening and is the only thing that holds this back from a 5 stars, you can see in the pictures what he has done and him in the act, slowly moving across the bridge

Previously called Solf√©rino footbridge (after the battle of Solferino, 1859, Italy). The first bridge was inaugurated in 1861 by Napoleon III. Damaged by the impact of several ships on its structure, the bridge was demolished and replaced by a pedestrian footbridge in 1961. In 1992 it was demolished for the second time. It was rebuilt again in 1999.  It is said that the French composer Debussy had the idea of writing Nuages while contemplating the Seine from this footbridge. This bridge is also popularly known as the Bridge of Love.
Decent walking bridge, it can get you across the river to either the upper road or the walking path below.

Nice bridge to use between the two art museums. Covered with locks so it makes for nice pictures. A lot of scams and people selling stuff on here so be careful and don't mind them unless you want to lose money.
An awesome place to spend your evening, a pleasant river side where you can find many restaurants and cafes, You will get a nice view and cool breeze and the view of cruise ships

One of my favorite bridge in Paris! You have Orsay museum on a side and the Tuilerie garden on the other which makes it a perfect location. The quaie de seine below it is also full of people doing some sports, skateboard‚Ä¶ so very lively. Tips: go there to enjoy the sunset! You‚Äôll avoid the crowd :)
Beautiful bridge. Love locks all over the railings. Nice spot for photos and a pleasant walk to the right bank.
Been here a few times, great stroll across the bridge.  Tried to find my lock from my honey moon - no success :(.  Amazing view too.

Beautiful footbridge to walk on, connecting Jardin des Tuileries and Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay. According to Wikipedia, exotic woods like Brazilian trees are used on the decking of this bridge. Modern looking bridge but it has a nice warm feeling.  Top of the Eiffel tower can be seen from the bridge.
Beautifully designed walking bridge. Nice view of the river 'La Seine' and the famous 'bateaux mouches'. Do not miss the lovelocks..
It's the favorite place of couples, engaged or married people to write their names on a lock and throw the key to the river
Passerelle L√©opold-S√©dar-Senghor was built in 1997-1999, it is the newest bridge in Paris. Great construction!
‚ÄúFun story of "Lovers locks" on the sides of passerelle (not a bridge since only accessible for pedestrians...no cars)‚Äù. Awesome place for walking
We placed locker with our names here. Nice view of both sides of Seine.
Great views from the bridge and a superb alternative to Pont des Arts
Wonderful, beautiful, have some incredible vibes, a mark of the city of Paris, a point you need to go, I left a memory of mine there
Paris as Paris always brings some emotions and new smile.. üòä ‚Ä¶

I love this bridge! There are places to sit and watch the boats pass underneath on the Seine. There are lots of ppl during the day but at night is nicely lit with fewer people. And the Mus√©e d'Orsay is right in front of it.

We were in hurry in Paris with a small disappointment that  we missed the bridge with thousands locks! And suddenly it came before us while we are walking by the river as a family. We were so happy. The view of both sides of the bridge is spectacular. We crossed the bridge to take an Uber on the other side. It was a simply a gift for us.
Had a date with a loser there, good thing the bridge is pretty enough to compensate
Nice bridge to cross over Seine to other side

The Passerelle L√©opold-S√©dar-Senghor is a footbridge characterized by its modern and sleek design. It features a single arch made of steel and has a transparent glass floor, providing pedestrians with a unique view of the Seine River and the surrounding area.
Cool bridge for photographers
Perfect place to walk while visiting the city. Has a nice view of the Louvre Museum. Went there and it was really sunny so it was a nice view of the river as well.
Excelent place for walking, running, and more.
Excellent view on Bastille Day

Good place for taking interesting photos. But in two hours I've stayed around no yellow shirt runner has passed by. I almost went to ask a coach if he was willing to oblige... After I left, when I was up the wooden stairs in front of Musee D'Orsay, I saw a group of 10-12 joggers all in bright yellow t's!
beautiful place to walk around

Passerelle Leopold-Sedar-Senghor is a footbridge crossing of the Seine near to Musee d'Orsay in the 7th arrondissement of Paris. Originally a cast iron bridge was erected upon this location in 1861. However, the current single span bridge was constructed between 1997-1999.  It is a functional bridge, not particularly beautiful compared to other more decorative and historic bridges in Paris. What you will notice that is interesting are the many Love Locks which have been padlocked to the bridge, making it something of a new 'Bridge of Love' in Paris. There is also an interesting statue of 3rd U.S. President Thomas Jefferson on the Left Bank side of Passerelle Leopold-Sedar-Senghor.

Alternative for lovers to hang a lock... yet the real Pont des arts offers a beauiful photo opportunity infront of Ils de la cite!  Don't miss it!  This is a Pedestrian bridge the passerelle  L√©opold-S√©dar-Senghor and  is sometimes mistaken for Pont des arts because loving couples  now hang a lock on this bridge in a romantic gesture. Aspirant lockpickers, it is also an ideal place to train  skills and help preserve the bridgeüòâ  I must stress ...As alternative for the romantic gesture it s ok, Yet Pont des arts has a more romantic scenery, thus nicer photo opportunities right in front of √Æle de la cit√© that you should not miss..
One of the few bridges where you can put up locks on the railings :)
